captions.text:
Matthew, there is nothing in the laws of physics
to prevent nanobots, microscopic robots, from

circulating in the bloodstream and bulking
us up, strengthening our bones, giving us

the power of Superman. There is nothing in
the laws of physics to prevent that.  However,

the reality is much, much more complicated. 
Let's take a look at nanotechnology today.

It's very primitive.  It is a multibillion
dollar industry only because we use it for

coatings, coatings to make fabric stronger
and coatings for different kinds of appliances.

We also use it in airbags.  Believe it or
not there is a tiny sensor, an accelerometer

in your airbag—compliments of nanotechnology—that
create the gigantic explosion of an airbag.

But that's today.  The promise is that in
the coming decades with carbon nanotubes,

with graphene, we'll create even new substances
which can replace the silicon of computers,

maybe even give us a space elevator.  Graphene
for example, is a substance made out of one-molecule-thick

layer of carbon.  Think about that.  Think
of like Saran Wrap made out of one-molecule-thick

carbon atoms.  That graphene is so strong
in principle you can take an elephant, put

the elephant on a pencil, suspend the pencil
on graphene and graphene will not break.

That is how strong it is.  It is the strongest
material known to science at the present time.

However, having these nanobots in our body—that
is decades away.  We can't even create a

nanobot that is large that will do most of
these things on a microscopic scale.  Forget

going down to the atomic scale.  So to summarize:
yes, in principle there is nothing in the

laws of physics to prevent nanobots from invigorating
us, changing our molecular structure, changing

our bone structure and skeleton.  However,
the practical implementation of that is staggering.

It's not going to happen for many decades
to come.

Michio Kaku:  Matthew, there is nothing in
the laws of physics to prevent nanobots, microscopic

robots, from circulating in the bloodstream
and bulking us up, strengthening our bones,

giving us the power of Superman. There is
nothing in the laws of physics to prevent

that.  However, the reality is much, much
more complicated.

Let's take a look at nanotechnology today. 
It's very primitive.  It is a multibillion

dollar industry only because we use it for
coatings, coatings to make fabric stronger

and coatings for different kinds of appliances. 
We also use it in airbags.  Believe it or

not there is a tiny sensor, an accelerometer
in your airbag—compliments of nanotechnology—that

create the gigantic explosion of an airbag. 
But that's today.  The promise is that in

the coming decades with carbon nanotubes,
with graphene, we'll create even new substances

which can replace the silicon of computers,
maybe even give us a space elevator.  Graphene

for example, is a substance made out of one-molecule-thick
layer of carbon.  Think about that.  Think

of like Saran Wrap made out of one-molecule-thick
carbon atoms.  That graphene is so strong

in principle you can take an elephant, put
the elephant on a pencil, suspend the pencil

on graphene and graphene will not break. 
That is how strong it is.  It is the strongest

material known to science at the present time. 
However, having these nanobots in our body—that

is decades away.  We can't even create a
nanobot that is large that will do most of

these things on a microscopic scale.  Forget
going down to the atomic scale.  So to summarize:

yes, in principle there is nothing in the
laws of physics to prevent nanobots from invigorating

us, changing our molecular structure, changing
our bone structure and skeleton.  However,

the practical implementation of that is staggering. 
It's not going to happen for many decades
to come.

comments.text:
Stupaod, sorry if I came off as too mean. I never meant to say that 
humanity was perfect. What I meant was the potential it has. I don't like 
it when people try to bash on potential.
I mean, if everyone tells a child that the child will never amount to 
anything, what is the chance that that child will be motivated to do 
anything? Same thing here.
If people keep telling each other that humanity is going to fail, will 
anyone actually try to save it? The problem with most of the world is that 
the latter is the more prevalent notion in society.
Yes, my ideals are probably just daydreams, unlikely to ever happen, but if 
I toss it aside then it will become NO dream, with no chance of occurring.

The world wasn't made in a day, and the life that came to it was no small 
stroke of luck either. So, I think it would be correct to assume that a 
peaceful human race will take eons to create, and a sumptuous amount of aid 
from Lady Luck to build upon. Doesn't mean it can't happen, though. The 
world is still like a child, with no parent to guide it, so the world has 
to take the hard route to learning and maturity. It would be foolish to 
expect the world to become a utopia right off the bat.

Sorry if I ramble too much. It's just that I can't think of a shorter way 
to say what's on my mind... also...
Can we drop this stuff please? I just caught my email note for this by 
chance. I rarely use this account. I think everyone here can agree that 
this thread has gotten repetitive, and not to mention annoying... not 
pointing names here...
comments.author: Munchy Minnow

comments.text:
Graphene isn't only the strongest substance: it is also
1. a battery
2. a semconductor,
3. a superconductor, and 
3. a solar panel. 
And since it's carbon-based, it can be mass-produced. 
 So this miracle-substance can be used to produce buildings and vehicles 
which are also supercomputers and power-conduits which collect and store 
solar energy. 
In fact, a vehicle constructed of graphene could have panels of virtually 
any size since they're so light and strong, and they could unfold like a 
giant map to collect enough solar energy to accelerate at 1g for manned 
vehicles, to 1000's of g's for unmanned ones.  Such a vehicle could fly to 
the moon in an hour, Mars in a day, the asteroid belt in 2 days, or Jupiter 
in a matter of days-- all on solar-powered plasma-drive, because of the 
huge energy-mass ratio.  
Another possibility of graphene is self-replicating machines, which convert 
local carbon into machines that either perform functions, or create other 
machines; this could convert cabon-based planets into livable cities in a 
matter of days, complete with solar-powered electricity and breathable 
oxygen. This could convert  the  moon into a giant city in days, Mars in 
weeks, along with the asteroid belt into giant space-cities (since it's 3/4 
carbon), and  with the moons of Jupiter and Saturn in roughly the same 
time. Mercury could also be converted in about a day, due to the intense 
solar energy. ﻿

comments.author: tiffsaver

comments.text:
This guy's video's are awesome. I'd have to disagree with him about the 
carbon nanotube space elevator though. The longest reported carbon nanotube 
synthesized was ~18.5 cm, and they can't be conveniently grown to more than 
1 cm or so. On top of that, no material is defect free, meaning the 
theoretical strength misrepresents it's true strength. Also, the hallmark 
of good structural engineering materials is also safe failure, but carbon 
nanotubes build up a ton of elastic energy before they fracture suddenly 
(i.e. not safely). It would be a great feat of engineering these problems 
can be circumvented, but it will be a long time before carbon nanotubes and 
graphene are useful outside of composite materials.﻿
comments.author: Sankalp Kota

comments.author: mraccident

comments.text:
So I have to comment on this. Dr. Kaku says something quite silly here: 
saran wrap made of one layer of graphene could support the weight of an 
elephant standing on a pencil....

It is popularized, online, that graphene as thick as saran wrap could 
support an elephant. This is wrong for many reasons; you cannot stack 
graphene sheets to the thickness of saran wrap because then you're back to 
graphite. And a layer of graphite this thickness would be difficult to 
handle without crumbling, let alone the elephant!

So what if you take the atoms in a sheet of graphene and make those as 
thick as saran wrap? Well, not even nuclear physics allows for this 
experiment, so it's literally NOT physically possible! That's as valid as 
saying "if you could enhance the strength of the weakest material ever, it 
could potentially be the strongest material ever."﻿
comments.author: no

comments.text:
+BigRalphSmith
responding to wrongness of this order of magnitude is tempting, but I know 
it will get me nowhere. you are lost friend.
comments.author: no

comments.text:
+no
*no sticks fingers in ears and goes "lalalalalalalalalala..."
Graphene and graphite are both made of the same type of atoms (carbon) but 
the atomic structure of graphene is different from graphite. Also, graphene 
is stable. What that means is that stacking graphene sheets does not form 
graphite (the lattice structure does not change from the mono-atomic 
structure of graphene to the 2 dimensional honeycomb structure of graphite 
all by itself).
Can graphene be produced from graphite? Sure. That's not the same thing as 
"graphite is made out of graphene".
That's like saying "if I stack pencil leads together, I'll get diamonds".
comments.author: BigRalphSmith

comments.text:
+BigRalphSmith
Okay, well you are blatantly wrong. Graphite is "made of graphene." You can 
wikipedia graphite if you want, the answer is there, or you can take the 
word of a chemist. Or you can just delete your comment, because everything 
you say from this point on is invalid and will be disregarded, hopefully by 
the general public.
comments.author: no

comments.text:
+no And you don't think that using numbers would be even more opaque to the 
average person than to use some type of descriptive verbiage? I think I'll 
just have to disagree with you there.
Also, graphene and graphite are two completely different structures. 
Graphite is not "made of graphene". They are both made of carbon atoms but 
that's about the only similarity.
comments.author: BigRalphSmith

comments.text:
+BigRalphSmith I think the key distinction that warranted Brock's confusion 
is that two things occur by the illustration: a hypothetical situation and 
wrong information. The hypothetical situation consists of an elephant on a 
pencil. The elephant represents a real mass and a pencil represents a real 
surface area. From the mass, the force of gravity, and the surface area, 
one could in theory derive a very rough estimation for pressure. Also, a 
pencil is filled with graphite, composed of grapheme, so if what Dr. Kaku 
proposes is true, then a pencil should be able to support the weight of an 
elephant because it's thousands of times the thickness of Saran wrap! 
(Gotcha-- we both know it couldn't) But I digress...
The more important thing is that inflating the properties of graphene does 
not help explain the properties; it simply exaggerates them. There's no 
physical realities in the information he provides.
To illustrate the concept, I would simply compare numbers. I'm sure 
somewhere someone has tested/calculated the tensile strengths of atomically 
thin sheets of materials in vacuums, and I'm sure graphene's tensile 
strength is orders of magnitude larger. But let's do away with these 
imaginary properties, please?
comments.author: no

comments.text:
+Brock X
And, just like you, there will be others that don't quite understand what's 
being said or illustrated but that does not mean there won't be many who do 
see it for what it is.
We all know that an elephant would not be able to balance, or be balanced, 
on a pencil. That should have been your first clue. Obviously a pencil 
can't support an elephant in any position.
When you see obvious absurdities in a verbal illustration, that is your 
first hint to look immediately past that absurdity to see the actual point 
of the lay-explanation.

I got it. I understood the explanation for what it was. What example would 
you guys have used to illustrate the concept?
comments.author: BigRalphSmith

comments.text:
+Brock X
+BigRalphSmith
Okay, graphene CAN provide a suspended surface and it CANNOT support 
weight. The problem is that people hear this video and think they can erect 
space elevators from the allotropes of carbon and try getting money from 
Congress for it! (true story) Guess who Congressmen are? Laymen. I hate to 
bring politics and money into the discussion, but the reality is that 
scientific concepts are truths. What Dr. Kaku said made no sense. Let's 
review: 1) despite popular belief, the laws of physics prevent graphene 
from reaching the thickness of Saran wrap 2) stacking sheets of graphene to 
create graphite the thickness of Saran wrap will not bear weight. So at 
what point did Dr. Kaku do a good job explaining this concept? *drops mic*
comments.author: no

comments.text:
+BigRalphSmith Yes. Me being a layman I assume that since I thought that it 
could support an elephant other laymen would think the same thing.
comments.author: Brock Jones

comments.text:
+Brock X
I see. So, you've decided that because you were not clear on the concept, 
then no one else will be? Because you did not find the illustration 
understandable, that that makes it completely opaque to everyone else?
If graphene could be manipulated to provide a suspended surface, it COULD 
support a weight equivalent to an elephant balancing on  pencil. That's the 
point.
It was an illustration, not a real world application.
comments.author: BigRalphSmith

comments.text:
+BigRalphSmith If you are a layman then you are not going to realize that 
this a concept and cannot actually be used to support massive amounts of 
weight. I know that since I am fairly layman about graphene I thought that 
you could actually support an elephant. I find it misleading to keep using 
that example and not clarify that graphene cannot support an elephant.
comments.author: Brock Jones

comments.text:
+no
Don't you think that his example was not intended to represent a real-world 
scenario but rather to express, in terms a layman might find more 
understandable, the concept of the kind of strength we are talking about? 
No one said anything about actually supporting anything with graphene. His 
illustration was for conveying a concept to those not equipped to 
understand the actual science.
You took a very simple verbal illustration and over-thought it.
comments.author: BigRalphSmith

comments.text:
+Brock X
Well, graphene has many practical purposes. It is very strong for it's 
1-atom thickness. So strong that you can actually make a 1 cm^2 piece of 
it, which is very transparent, but surprisingly you can see it. Some 
believe these can be used as inexpensive water filters. (They let water 
through the hexagon holes and hold back other junk!) Graphene's also 
conductive, so it's already found a couple uses in industry. It is actually 
very strong, maybe the strongest material known to man for it's size, I 
don't know. But, the whole elephant-pencil deal is silly: people will not 
be making weight-baring materials out of graphene, and I highly doubt 
graphite will play that role, either.
comments.author: no

comments.text:
+no Hmm interesting. So there isn't really a practice purpose for graphene 
then?
comments.author: Brock Jones

comments.text:
+Brock X
Excellent question, Brock! This drives at the question of what graphene is, 
which I believe is not explained at all in this video. The short answer to 
your question is no; graphene is an atomically thin, 2-dimensional sheet of 
conjugated carbon atoms. In contrast, graphite is a 3-dimensional stack of 
graphene sheets. Sounds too simple? The 2010 Nobel prize in physics was 
awarded to two very smart gentlemen for literally taking scotch tape, 
sticking it to a block of graphite, and pulling off a single sheet of 
graphene. Win.
comments.author: no
